column4: hi question, i want to know something about filesystem.. No not which is better and faster for boot. No i want to know which filesystem is best for datastorage.It has to be safe, stable less errors and a undelete function.. what do you think?
what style of undelete do you need?
what type of undelete though?  recyclebin style, full archival, full-archival with branching?
so you need historical?  what granularity?  (i.e., if a program writes something to a file every 10 seconds for a year, do you need every version?)
would something like a write-once file system be appropriate then?
write-once???
files are readonly once written
but the duplicates would have to be undeletable for all time?
then it'd be easier to have a file system that's write once, and then another file system that just links to iot
do you need to be able to recover from somebody blanking out a photo?
I'd recommend sticking with ext3 then, it's the most stable file system on linux
okay thanks
you can go poking through the contents with any disk editor

ext3 just tries really really hard not to lose stuff in the first place (/lost+found generally contains stuff it finds after a hard reboot, generally stuff that was unlinked, but the metadata wasn't updated yet)
lost-as-in-deleted-files really shouldn't be easily recoverable, and ext3 is robust to pretty much everything else that would cause it, beyond hardware failure
might be non-trivial to set up, but it should be quite possible
are you familiar with the command line methods of configuring interfaces?
should probably get in the habit of mv'ing stuff instead, or just using gnome/nautilus (which has a trash bin)
i prefer using networkmanager but i want to do this. have two account. one is connect to wirless and the other is connect to wired network
but I generally appreciate it that stuff (such as private keys) is actually gone when I tell the system to remove it :)
or start using version control on your photo's
but what about my plan with two networks???
